results.headline: 'Poster Boy' Sets a New Agenda for a Conservative Senator

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Poster Boy

results.summary_short: A polemic masquerading as a movie, “Poster Boy” unspools like a humorless lecture on right-wing homophobia.

results.headline: Children on the Run Are Bound by Blood in 'Moonlight'

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Moonlight

results.summary_short: In this English-language Dutch thriller, a 13-year-old girl and a young Afghan drug courier fall in love while fleeing his employers.

results.headline: 'King Leopold’s Ghost' Recounts Tales of Unimaginable Terror

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of King Leopold's Ghost

results.summary_short: Europe’s genocidal adventures in Africa receive a passionate reckoning in this ambitious documentary based on Adam Hochschild’s best-selling history of the same title.

results.headline: Adventures in Alternative Education in 'Accepted'

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Accepted

results.summary_short: A clever slacker and his oddball crew invent a phony college in this passable example of that oxymoronic genre, the Hollywood comedy about sticking it to the man.

results.headline: Irish Independence in the 60’s, With Affection and Sarcasm, in ‘Rocky Road to Dublin’

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Rocky Road to Dublin

results.summary_short: This 1968 survey of Irish life remains noteworthy for its historical perspective, sardonic tone, lively structure and finely etched black and white cinematography.

results.headline: Gifted Kids Band Together to Save Earth in 'Zoom'

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Zoom

results.summary_short: Too infantile for tweens and too stagnant for tots, “Zoom” bleeds boredom from every frame.

results.headline: In Creep-Out Film 'Pulse,' Teenagers Face Evil Screen Savers

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Pulse

results.summary_short: The American version of Kiyoshi Kurosawa's “Pulse” mimics the plot fundamentals, but lacks any traces of Mr. Kurosawa’s creepy minimalism and conceptual rigor.

results.headline: ‘Kabhi Alvida Naa Kehna,’ a Bollywood Divorce Tale

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Kabhi Alvida Naa Kehna

results.summary_short: Only in Bollywood would the standard-issue marital-infidelity tale include disco-style musical numbers and clock in at almost three and a half hours.

results.headline: ‘House of Sand’: A Mother, Her Daughter, and Brazil’s Bleak Yet Lovely Land

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The House of Sand

results.summary_short: Beautifully shot in a sandy, remote corner of northern Brazil, this lovely film tells the story of three generations of women.

results.headline: In ‘Half Nelson,’ a Student Knows a Teacher’s Secret

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Half Nelson

results.summary_short: "Half Nelson" is that rarest of marvels — an American fiction film that wears its political heart on its sleeve.

results.headline: Hip-Hop and Ballet Cross Paths in 'Step Up'

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Step Up

results.summary_short: A rough Baltimore kid, armed only with a killer smile and hip-hop moves, falls for a classically trained dancer in another retread of "Save the Last Dance."

results.headline: Scenes of Loneliness and Disconnect in 'Hamilton'

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Hamilton

results.summary_short: Without plot or incident, and with only the flimsiest of characterizations, "Hamilton" operates primarily on the level of suggestion and insinuation.

results.headline: Contemplating a Fling Across a Divide in 'Conversations With Other Women'

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Conversations With Other Women

results.summary_short: Hans Canosa's studied debut feature stars Aaron Eckhart and Helena Bonham Carter as old flames who meet, years after parting, and have a short fling.

results.headline: Searching for a Spiritual Shangri La in 'The Celestine Prophecy'

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Celestine Prophecy

results.summary_short: A delectable fusion of New Age babble and luridly bad filmmaking based on the best-selling 1993 book by James Redfield.

results.headline: Violent Cretins Play a Game of Cat-and-Mouse in 'Calvaire'

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Ordeal

results.summary_short: Directed by the newcomer Fabrice du Welz, the Belgian horror film “Calvaire” is pompous, but not without talent or shivers.

results.headline: 'The Beales of Grey Gardens' Profiles Eccentrics in East Hampton

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Beales of Grey Gardens

results.summary_short: The Maysles brothers dig into their archives for this collection of outtakes from “Grey Gardens.”

results.headline: Pinned Under the Weight of Skyscrapers and History in 'World Trade Center'

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of World Trade Center

results.summary_short: Oliver Stone has taken a public tragedy and turned it into something at once genuinely stirring and terribly sad.

results.headline: A Man at 30, When Fuddy Meets Duddy, in 'The Trouble With Men and Women'
results.display_title: The Trouble With Men and Women

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Trouble With Men and Women

results.summary_short: Although the setting of this tiny, well-acted movie is contemporary London, it could be any European or American city where people mate and hope for the best.

results.headline: Breaking All the Rules, 21st-Century Style, in ‘Satellite’

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Satellite

results.summary_short: This captivating romantic fairy tale for grown-ups could be described as a yuppie “Bonnie and Clyde” in which alienated corporate climbers break the rules.

results.headline: In 'Lunacy,' a Degenerate Journey, and Many Moving Parts

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Lunacy

results.summary_short: The mad and the sane take a leisurely spin around the dance floor in the Czech filmmaker Jan Svankmajer’s feature-length phantasmagoria.
